Package org.tquadrat.foundation.javadoc

@API(status=STABLE, since="0.0.1") package org.tquadrat.foundation.javadoc

The classes in the package org.tquadrat.foundation.javadoc provide some extensions to the standard JavaDoc extensions.

An older version of this tool provided a custom Doclet that extended StandardDoclet; it did some pre-processing and then delegated the work to the parent.

The new implementation here is completely based on the new Java 9 JavaDoc APIs, and will implement all functions only as instances of Taglet.

Basically, the extensions are used by the Foundation Library itself, but they are available for any other projects, too. To activate the extensions in your project, add the following parameters to your JavaDoc call:


  -tagletpath <path/to/>org.tquadrat.foundation.javadoc-0.1.0.jar:<path/to/>apiguardian-api-1.1.2.jar:<path/to/>jakarta.activation-2.0.1.jar

  -taglet org.tquadrat.foundation.javadoc.AuthorTaglet
  -taglet org.tquadrat.foundation.javadoc.AnchorTaglet
  -taglet org.tquadrat.foundation.javadoc.HRefTaglet
  -taglet org.tquadrat.foundation.javadoc.IgnoreTaglet
  -taglet org.tquadrat.foundation.javadoc.IncludeTaglet
  -taglet org.tquadrat.foundation.javadoc.InspiredTaglet
  -taglet org.tquadrat.foundation.javadoc.ModifiedTaglet
  -taglet org.tquadrat.foundation.javadoc.NoteTaglet
  -taglet org.tquadrat.foundation.javadoc.ThanksTaglet
  -taglet org.tquadrat.foundation.javadoc.ToDoTaglet
  -taglet org.tquadrat.foundation.javadoc.UmlGraphLinkTaglet
  -taglet org.tquadrat.foundation.javadoc.UnderlineTaglet

  -tag note
  -tag param
  -tag return
  -tag throws
  -tag author
  -tag extauthor
  -tag thanks
  -tag modified
  -tag version
  -tag since
  -tag see
  -tag inspired
  -tag UMLGraph.link
  -tag todo

In detail, the following new documentation tags can be used:

@extauthor

A replacement for the default @author taglet that provides the author's email as a hyperlink.

This means that the tag requires the reference to the author in the format

  @extauthor <name> - <email address>

Basically, this is the name of the author, followed by their email address, separated by a hyphen ("-" or &#x2d;), surrounded by blanks.

If there is no email address, the output is the same as for the standard @author taglet.

Implemented by the class AuthorTaglet.

@thanks

Use this tag to add a reference to the author of the model for the current piece of code. It uses the same format as the @extauthor tag described above.

Implemented by the class ThanksTaglet.

@modified

When code written by somebody else was modified, this tag can be used to refer to the editor. It makes also use of the format as described for the @extauthor above.

Implemented by the class ModifiedTaglet.

@inspired

Sometimes a piece of code was inspired by a document of some kind, a description of an algorithm, a product white paper, or whatever. This tag allows to add a reference to that source of inspiration. The text for this taglet has some limitations as described in the documentation for the implementing class InspiredTaglet.

@note

With this tag, it is easy to add important notes to the documentation for an element. All notes will be added to a bullet list placed immediately beneath the documentation text (given that the tag sequence shown above is used). The text for the @note is somehow limited, refer to the documentation for the implementing class NoteTaglet.

@todo <task.list>

This tag can be used to add a list of open issues to the documentation for a module or a package. <task.list> is the name of a file with the open issue; the documentation for the implementing class ToDoTaglet provides information about the format of the file and how it will be retrieved during the Javadoc generation.

@UMLGraph.link

With this tag a UML graph can be added to the documentation for a class.

Implemented by the class UmlGraphLinkTaglet.

{@anchor #<name> <text>}

This tag allows to add an HTML anchor to the documentation, where <name> is the name of that anchor, and <text> the anchor text. The hash symbol ("#") before the anchor name is mandatory!

Implemented by the class AnchorTaglet.

{@href <url> <text>} or {@href <url>}

With this tag a hyperlink can be added to the documentation; different from the {@link} and {@linkplain} tags, this is used to refer to external resources. Obviously, <url> is the target URL, while <text>} is the clickable text. If the latter is omitted, the URL itself will be used instead.

Implemented by the class HRefTaglet.

{@underline <text>}

If text needs to be underlined, this is the tag.

Implemented by the class UnderlineTaglet.

{@include <file>:[<processMode>]}}

This tag allows to include other files from the source path into the JavaDoc documentation. For the details, refer to the documentation for the implementing class IncludeTaglet.

{@ignore <text>}

The standard tag @hidden allows to exclude the whole documentation for an element (a type, method or field) from the generated Javadoc documentation. With the tag @ignore it is possible to exclude just the text inside. This can be useful when the comments for the generated documentation are difficult to read.

Implemented by the class UmlGraphLinkTaglet.

  • Related Packages
    Package
    Description
    org.tquadrat.foundation.javadoc.internal
    Several internal classes for the taglet implementations.
    org.tquadrat.foundation.javadoc.umlgraph
    The classes required to generate the UML graph for the UMLGraph.Link tag.
  • Classes
    Class
    Description
    AnchorTaglet
    This inline tag inserts an HTML anchor into the documentation that can be used for references to the location of that anchor.
    AuthorTaglet
    This taglet replaces the standard @author taglet. It is different in the way that it provides the author's email address as a hyperlink.
    CreateSourceHTML
    A tool that can be used to create an HTML file suitable as a documentation extension for a JavaDoc from an arbitrary text file.
    HRefTaglet
    This inline tag inserts a hyperlink to an external URL into the documentation.
    IdeaStarter
    If a program will be started from IntelliJ IDEA, the args argument to IdeaStarter.main(String...) has always values.
    IgnoreTaglet
    The contents of this inline tag will be ignored for the generation of the Javadoc output.
    IncludeTaglet
    This taglet allows to include the contents of an external file into the JavaDoc documentation.
    InspiredTaglet
    This taglet is used to add a reference to a document of some kind that inspired the current piece of code, either in its functionality or its implementation.
    JavadocStarter
    Executes the JavaDoc tool with a bunch of default parameters.
    ModifiedTaglet
    This taglet is used to refer to the author of the modifications for a piece of code that was originally written by somebody else (named in the @author or the @extauthor tag).
    NoteTaglet
    This taglet is used to add an important note to the documentation for an element.
    Starter
    Deprecated, for removal: This API element is subject to removal in a future version.
    This program was replaced by JavadocStarter.
    ThanksTaglet
    This taglet is used to refer to the author of the model for the current piece of code or the person who provided the idea for that code.
    ToDoTaglet
    With this taglet, it is possible to add a list of open points to the documentation of a module or a package.
    UmlGraphLinkTaglet
    When this tag is added to the documentation of a class, a UML graph will be created for this class and added to the documentation.
    UnderlineTaglet
    This inline tag allows to underline a sequence of text.
